item.title: At the Olympics, I Saw the Difference Between Nationalism and Patriotism
item.description: Nationalism may be on the rise, but at the Olympics our shared humanity easily crossed borders.
item.dc:creator: David Litt

item.title: Ukraine Has Passed a Point of No Return
item.description: Four years that changed everything.
item.dc:creator: M. Gessen and Mila Teshaieva
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Mila Teshaieva for The New York Times

item.title: Inside Iran’s Preparation for War and Plans for Survival
item.description: Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has entrusted Ali Larijani, the top national security official, to ensure the Islamic Republic endures possible war and assassination.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ali Larijani, the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council of Iran, in May 2024.

item.title: How the Times Weather Team Tracks Big Storms: More Data, Less Hype
item.description: When making forecasts, our reporters aim to visualize severe weather possibilities rather than focus on the most dire predictions. A possible blizzard this weekend is the latest test.
item.dc:creator: John Keefe, Erin McCann, Judson Jones, Amy Graff, Nazaneen Ghaffar and Seth Carlson

media:content.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: It’s been a rough winter in New York City and many other parts of the country. The Times Weather team tries to keep readers informed ahead of a storm.

item.title: Quote of the Day: After Enduring Horrors, Offering ‘A Hymn to Life’
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 22, 2026.

item.title: Trump Looks Ahead to Summit With China’s Xi, but Tariffs and Taiwan Loom
item.description: President Trump said his planned meeting with President Xi Jinping would be a grand display, but tensions over trade and defense could dampen the mood.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The last time President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China met was in Busan, South Korea, last October.

item.title: Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo Leads Norway to Record Olympic Medal Haul
item.description: Norway, led by the cross-country skiing sensation Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo, topped the medal table for the fourth straight Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Louise Krüger

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Fans of Norway at the Anterselva Biathlon Arena in Antholz-Anterselva, Italy, this month.

item.title: The A.I. Evangelists on a Mission to Shake Up Japan
item.description: Team Mirai, a political party founded by software engineers, won 11 seats in Japan’s legislature by promising chatbots, self-driving buses and high-tech jobs.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya

media:content.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times

item.title: After Battling on Ice and Snow, Athletes Face Post-Olympics Blues
item.description: “It just goes by so quick,” one speedskater said. Some Olympic officials are trying to help competitors better navigate the aftermath of elite competition.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The end of competition can be difficult to navigate for Olympic athletes, who may face an emotional roller coaster when the spotlight fades.

item.title: Rose Byrne Can, and Does, Do It All
item.description: An Oscar nominee for a movie in which everything crashes down on her (literally), Byrne is shifting gears with the Broadway comedy “Fallen Angels.”
item.dc:creator: Leah Greenblatt and Sam Hellmann
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

media:content.media:credit: Sam Hellmann for The New York Times

item.title: The Ex-Taxi Driver at the Center of Russia’s Shadow War
item.description: The Kremlin’s sabotage campaign against European allies of Ukraine has been escalating. It needs people like Aleksei Kolosovsky, 42, to carry it out.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Adam Goldman

media:content.media:credit: Norbert Ofmanski/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A 2024 arson attack outside Warsaw was one of several plots carried out in Europe by a criminal network on behalf of Russian intelligence services, according to European officials.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 22, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 22, 2026.

item.title: Tom Noonan, Actor Renowned for Onscreen Menace, Dies at 74
item.description: He played memorable screen villains, notably a psychopath in “Manhunter,” but also wrote, directed and starred in well-received plays at a theater he founded in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:credit: Franco Origlia/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Tom Noonan in 2015. “Anybody who saw him as an actor would know that he was the most shockingly present, immediate, in-the-moment actor,” said the actor and writer Wallace Shawn.

item.title: Muere Willie Colón, leyenda de la salsa, a los 75 años
item.description: Trombonista, cantante, director de orquesta, compositor y arreglista, colaboró con Rubén Blades en “Siembra”, un disco que se convirtió en uno de los álbumes de salsa más vendidos de todos los tiempos.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Adam Bernstein

media:content.media:credit: Chad Batka para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Willie Colón presentándose en Nueva York en 2009. Su álbum debut de 1967, El Malo, impulsó una carrera de casi seis décadas.

item.title: Willie Colón: 14 Essential Songs and Albums
item.description: The trombonist, singer, bandleader, composer and producer from the Bronx helped shape the sound of salsa.
item.dc:creator: Ed Morales

media:content.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Willie Colón onstage in 2009. The songwriter and bandleader, who died at 75, was a giant on Fania Records and beyond.

item.title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
item.description: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: At its height, the strike by New York City nurses included nearly 15,000 workers.

item.title: Trump Pulls Support From House Republican Who Opposed Tariffs
item.description: The president yanked his endorsement of Representative Jeff Hurd of Colorado, imperiling Republicans’ chances of holding onto his seat as they brace for midterm losses.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Tim Balk

item.title: 2 Skiers Are Injured After Being Buried in Utah Avalanche
item.description: The men were skiing on Saturday in a backcountry area of the Big Cottonwood Canyon near Salt Lake City, said officials, who urged caution in unstable snow conditions.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:credit: Salt Lake County Sheriff's Office
media:content.media:description: The men were near the Butler Fork Trail when the avalanche occurred, the authorities said.

item.title: Traveling This Weekend? Here’s What to Know About the Snowstorm.
item.description: A major winter storm on Sunday and Monday is expected to bring delays and cancellations across much of the Northeast.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner and Kim Bhasin

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An industrial snow-melting machine at LaGuardia Airport in New York after a major snowstorm in January.

item.title: Political Drama ‘Yellow Letters’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
item.description: The film, from the director Ilker Catak, explores political repression in Turkey. Another movie set in the country, “Salvation,” took the runner-up prize.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers

media:content.media:credit: Nadja Wohlleben/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The director Ilker Catak won best film for “Yellow Letters” at the Berlin Film Festival on Saturday.

item.title: Kennedy Center Performance Canceled After Substance Poured on Ice Rink
item.description: An individual poured an unknown dark liquid onto a temporary skating rink at the Kennedy Center late Thursday night, in what the venue called a “calculated” attack.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Canadian figure-skating troupe Le Patin Libre performing at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts this month.

item.title: Books of the Bible
item.description: Jill Rafaloff and Michelle Sontarp’s collaboration takes us to school, but it’s all in good fun.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Three Lions/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: You’ll have to keep your stories straight to figure out today’s theme.

item.title: Willie Colón, a Luminary of Salsa Music, Dies at 75
item.description: A trombonist, singer, bandleader, composer and arranger, he collaborated with Rubén Blades on “Siembra,” a 1978 release that became one of the top-selling salsa albums of all time.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Adam Bernstein

media:content.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Willie Colón performing in New York in 2009. His 1967 debut album, “El Malo,” propelled a career spanning nearly six decades.

item.title: Nine Bodies of Skiers Recovered in Deadly Sierra Nevada Avalanche, Officials Say
item.description: A ninth victim who had been missing was found and recovered, officials said Saturday, from an avalanche that was the deadliest in modern California history.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín and Dave Philipps

media:content.media:credit: Fred Greaves/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Search and rescue personnel near a trail leading to the avalanche site near Soda Springs, Calif., on Saturday.

item.title: Iran’s Students Hold Anti-Regime Protests as Universities Reopen
item.description: Students helped grow initial protests into a national movement crushed by the government. As the new semester began, they chanted and marched again.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar, Pranav Baskar and Devon Lum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators gathering at Amirkabir University in Tehran, in an image from a social media post that was verified by The New York Times.

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.description: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order in April that imposed tariffs on countries around the world. The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that Mr. Trump had exceeded his authority.

item.title: Prosecutors Oppose Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs’s Appeal, Asserting Sentence Was Just
item.description: Mr. Combs, who is serving a 50-month sentence after his conviction on prostitution-related charges, has argued that a judge sentenced him improperly.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: In court papers on Friday, prosecutors argued that the judge who sentenced Sean Combs had rightly taken into consideration how the women had been treated while they acceded to his sexual demands.

item.title: For Dutch speedskater, age doesn’t matter.
item.description: Jorrit Bergsma, a gold medalist back in 2014, is now 40. But he rolled back the years to win gold.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Ohio Woman Who Fatally Drugged 4 Men Is Handed 4 Life Sentences
item.description: The woman, Rebecca Auborn, pleaded guilty to murder in December. The men, whom she had met for sex in exchange for money, overdosed on fentanyl, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz

media:content.media:credit: USA Today Network, via Reuters Connect
media:content.media:description: Rebecca Auborn with her defense attorney, Mark Hunt, at her sentencing on Thursday. She said in court that she was “truly sorry.”

item.title: The Queen Stuck by Prince Andrew. King Charles Is Pulling Away
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former prince, is getting no help from the throne as the crisis over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Richard Pohle
media:content.media:description: Prince Andrew, as he was then known, escorted his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, to a memorial service for his father, Prince Philip, at Westminster Abbey in London in March 2022.

item.title: Theodore Conklin, 77, Dies; His Rescue of an Inn Helped Save Sag Harbor
item.description: By rehabilitating the American Hotel, he turned a hard-luck village on the East End of Long Island into a mecca for pop stars and plumbers alike.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: At Least 10 Killed in Lebanon, Officials Say, After Israel Strikes Hezbollah
item.description: The Lebanese militant group said eight of its members were among those killed late Friday. The attacks threaten to further destabilize an already tenuous cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Hwaida Saad

media:content.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Coffins draped in fabric bearing the symbol of Hezbollah are carried through the village of Nabi Sheet, eastern Lebanon, on Saturday.

item.title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
item.description: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The JPMorgan Chase headquarters in Midtown Manhattan late last year.

item.title: Young Skaters Assist With Figure Skating Competitions While Aspiring to the Olympics
item.description: Young skaters known as flower kids jump into action. They have their own Olympic dreams.
item.dc:creator: Weiyi Cai

item.title: Tras el fallo contra los aranceles, ¿qué pasará con los acuerdos comerciales?
item.description: La decisión de la Corte Suprema de invalidar gran parte de los aranceles del presidente Trump genera interrogantes sobre el futuro de los acuerdos alcanzados con los principales socios comerciales de Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Meaghan Tobin, Eshe Nelson, Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis, Alex Travelli, Choe Sang-Hun, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: En octubre, el presidente Trump firmó un acuerdo comercial con la primera ministra de Japón, Sanae Takaichi, en Tokio.

item.title: Powder’s Siren Song: The Risks and Rewards of Backcountry Skiing
item.description: A string of recent tragedies, including a fatal avalanche near Lake Tahoe and an unusually deadly winter in Europe, has cast a spotlight on the sport’s inherent dangers.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Hirschfeld

media:content.media:credit: Anthony Edwards/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Recent storms have dumped huge amounts of snow in the Sierra Nevada, increasing the danger of avalanches in the backcountry.

item.title: Problem With Artemis Rocket Will Delay NASA’s Moon Mission
item.description: The rocket will be removed from the launchpad in order for technicians to investigate and fix a malfunctioning helium system.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

media:content.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: NASA officials said on Saturday they had discovered a potential flaw while fueling the Artemis II rocket.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Global Tariff to 15 Percent
item.description: The move signaled that the president would press ahead with steep global import taxes despite the legal setback from the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said on social media that the new, global tariff of 15 percent would take effect immediately.

item.title: Por qué atacar a Irán podría ser más peligroso que capturar a Maduro
item.description: Las amplias capacidades militares de Irán y su red de aliados regionales podrían arrastrar a Estados Unidos a un conflicto prolongado.

item.title: Bill Mazeroski, 89, Whose 9th-Inning Blast Made Pirates Champs, Is Dead
item.description: It was Game 7 of the 1960 World Series, when an infielder known for his glove, not his bat, crushed the powerful Yankees with one swing, bringing joy to Pittsburgh.
item.dc:creator: David Margolick

media:content.media:credit: Bettmann, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Pittsburgh Pirate Bill Mazeroski is doused with champagne in the locker room after hitting the home run that won the 1960 World Series for Pittsburgh over the New York Yankees.

item.title: Cómo resistir el resto del invierno
item.description: El equipo de Well comparte sus consejos para lidiar con los desafíos de esta estación.

item.title: Limes and Lemons and Oranges, Oh My!
item.description: Baked lemon pudding, citrusy cheesecake and upside-down blood orange cake make the most of winter citrus.

item.title: Divide Among Supreme Court’s Conservatives Could Test Trump’s Agenda
item.description: In rejecting President Trump’s tariffs, the court’s six conservative justices displayed subtle differences in their views of executive power.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: After the tariffs decision, the Trump administration cannot assume that the justices nominated by Republican presidents will see things the same way.

item.title: Six Questions on the Future of Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the president’s tariffs has jolted Washington and the business world. Here’s what to watch next.

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Supreme Court dealt a major blow yesterday to President Trump’s tariff-driven trade policy.

item.title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
item.description: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.
item.dc:creator: Vivienne Walt

media:content.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The biggest tech companies are bolstering their lobbying efforts in Europe as several countries weigh teen social media bans.

item.title: Blizzard Warnings Issued for Swath of East Coast, Including NYC
item.description: The blizzard warnings are the first since 2017 for New York City. Forecasters said the city is expected to get up to 18 inches of snow, with two feet possible.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Judson Jones and Amy Graff

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A snowstorm in Manchester, Conn., in January 2025.

item.title: Searching for Rejuvenation Where Skiers Chase Olympic Gold
item.description: The thermal waters of the Italian Alps, long praised for their restorative properties, are well known to elite athletes. During the Winter Games, they’ve drawn spectators, too.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Gabriela Bhaskar
